text: Host defense mechanisms triggered by microbial lipoproteins through toll-like receptors .

The generation of cell - mediated immunity against many infectious pathogens involves the production of <extra_id_0> interleukin-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , a key signal of the innate immune system .
Yet , for many pathogens , the molecules that induce <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by macrophages and the mechanisms by which they do so remain undefined .

text: Here it is shown that microbial lipoproteins are potent stimulators of <extra_id_0> IL-12 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by human macrophages , and that induction is mediated by Toll-like receptors ( TLRs ) .

Several lipoproteins stimulated TLR - dependent transcription of inducible <extra_id_0> nitric oxide synthase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the production of nitric oxide , a powerful microbicidal pathway .

text: Activation of TLRs by microbial lipoproteins may initiate innate defense mechanisms against infectious pathogens .
